SC Still Debates
Conduct Code
BY PETER CINQUEGRANI
The Legal Rights Committee, headed by Cindy Simon, is
now working on the third draft
of the Conduct Code which it
hopes to have ready for referendum by March.
The code was originally
scheduled for completion in the
fall. Problems in acclimating the
new Student Council, the administrative reorganization which
caused communication difficulties and growing problems for the
Student Council in other areas
all delayed work on the Code.
Two factions are debating
what form the code will finally
take. The side headed by Simon
favorss a code which would "set
up general guidelines as to what

offenses the University will use
its own sanctions against." The
code as she conceives it would
deal soley with non-academic
offences, actions which would
directly or materially damage or
threaten the "health, safety and
welfare of the University community or damage the physical
facilities of the University." No
off-campus student activities
would come under the jurisdiction of the Code.
Accused students could
choose to have their cases heard
by either a Judicial Board
composed of five students or by
one of the deans. The proposkj
Code also calls for an appellate
process.

BY HARRY LERNER
On Tuesday, February 13,
frigid weather and hot tempers
created an ugly scene on the
10 am shuttle going to the East
Baltimore campus. The 9:30
shuttle never arrived. When
the 10:00 shuttle arrived, a
crowd of 60 would-be riders had
gathered to crowd onto the bus.
The problem increased when
those who had just arrived
pushed their way on ahead of
some people who had been
waiting for up to an hour in the
cold.
The driver, Bill Dorrell,
refused to leave with riders
standing in the aisle and on the
steps, but no passengers would
get off. Finally he, radioed the
Magsamen Bus Co. for instruc-

tions, and they called Hopkins
Secuirty. Four officers, including Security Manager Robert
Larkin, responded to the call.
Mark Warren, a medical
student, says that the Security
officers flew into a rage. He says
they were "screaming as loud as
they could, 'get off the bus or
we'll throw you off." Warren
admits that the riders' response
was,"if they didn't get down (to
East Baltimore) why should
anyone get down" and that
there was "verbal abuse back
and forth." He thinks "there
should have been an attempt to
reach an equitable solution, "
such as asking those who had
just arrived to wait, or putting
the University van into service.
Dr. Paul McHugh, Director

Reefer Reform 'letters to the editorl
It is a strange paradox that the increased use of the
drug cannabis among "respectable" middle-class citizens
seems if anything to have led to a more complacent
attitude toward the law forbidding the possession of
marijuana. But in the words of national NORML director
Larry Schott, "Pot has become so commonplace, it's not a
cultural symbol any more."
Yet the outlawed status of marijuana remains one of
the biggest single travesties perpetrated by the government
on our society today. The official hypocrisy engendered
by the current situation rivals the disastrous spectacle of
Prohibition. The frequent and flagrant flouting of the
marijuana law not only weakens the moral force of that
particular statute, it also subverts respect for the role of
law in an entire generation of citizens. Such a trend
cannot be tolerated; no society can be strong unless the
laws it establishes are enforced and observed to the fullest
extent by its good members.
In spite of the widespread disregard for the penalties
concerning cannabis consumption, the law takes a heavy
toll. Over 470,000 people were arrested in this country last
year on such charges, an all-time high. Of these cases, 90%
were for simple possession. The continued illegitimacy of
marijuana makes respectable citizenship quite tenuous for
anyone who uses the drug.
There are no solid reasons why growing, owning, and
smoking pot should remain illegal. The short-term effects
of the drug are in many respects comparable to those of
alcohol, which is allowed. However, it is much less disruptive of physical coordination, and there is no unpleasant
after-effect—read hangover. Neither have harmful long-term
effects been proven for moderate marijuana users. Used to
excess, like alcohol, cigarettes, or even food, it can wreck a
life.
In any case, since marijuana affects only people who
choose to use it, our government has no sacred right to
forbid the substance. Of course, in one important situation
a person's decision to get high could affect others, that is,
when that person is planning to drive an automobile. A
simple test has fortunately been devised to detect .drivers
under the influence of marijuana. Such "high driving"
should be subject to severe penalties just like drunk driving
now is.
The so-callocd "decriminalization" of marijuana which
has been introduced into some jurisdictions is but a
compromising solution at best. Traffic-sized fines for
marijuana violations arc even more hypocritical then the
present system, if that is possible. Only with total legalizadon of the distribution and possession of cannabis products can our society return to a sane. rational course.

Drivel
To the Editor:
It is with humble sincerity
that I submit this apology to
anyone who might have misconstrued the intent of my
previous letter (Hicks, January
26 issue). I am from a small
town in West Virginia where one
could not spit down Main street
on breezy day without hitting
one of my relatives. Needless to
say, any "degrading" remarks
pertaining to Mountain people
were strictly unintentional.
I was taken aback, however,
at the suppressive tone of "Slur
Stir" (February 9 issue). It is
my understanding that the first
amendment to the Constitution
(an excellent document, and I
recommend that those responsible for "Slur Stir" subject it to
perusal some evening when not
out crusading) guarantees that
freedom of the press shall not be
abridged. I expect that the
composers of this illiberal epistle
advocate censorship of the
News-Letter (themselves to be
the censors, no doubt).
"Slur Stir" might be passed
off as well intentioned drivel if it
did not contain implicit advocation of suppression of the free
press. The News-Letter is to be
commended for its willingness to
print even so reactionary an
opinion.
George Stanton

Way Out
To the Editor:
You know, if some things
weren't worth taking a stand for,
it wouldn't make a bit of difference what the administration
did to the Hopkins custodial
schedule...or what happened to
Ric Pfeffer...or how many
people were exterminated under
Mao Tse-Tung's regime...or how
a nation once begged to have a
murderer released to them that
they might crucify an innocent
man.
And when there isn't a
sufficient portion of the population willing to take a stand
against such injustices, they go
on and on, leaving succeeding
generations to clean up the mess.
Yet the guilt falls not solely into
the 'hands of those who perpetrate deceit, but also into the
hands of those who. stand idly
by. supposing that they are not
affected, nor responsible for
their own destiny.
As for myself, it would be
but a simple thing to shrug my
shoulders, finish writing my
thesis, and disappear into the
sunset, never again having to

concern myself with Hopkins or
the Twig fellowship I've coordinated here for the past few
years...And then it wouldn't
make a bit of difference what
Daisy Taylor wrote in last
week's News-Letter about The
Way.
But that's not the course I
choose to follow. It's not that
I'm so eminently noble, or
exceedingly virtuous, or endowed with wisdom that will
perish with my demise. Nor is it
that I follow The Way with
"blind devotion", and have sold
my soul to but a vain endeavor,
relishing in continual deceit of
my colleagues and peers, for I
am none of the above.
Yet I have taken a stand,
and will not begin to presume
that I have not the responsibility
to stLe what I know is true. I
trust that those who were
interested enough to read Ms.
Taylor's article will give at least
equal consideration to this point
of view.
This is not a complaint, nor
an attempt to set the record
straight. The article stands on
its own merits, or falls by its
lack thereof.
In the same
respect, if what we of The Way
believe and teach is truth, it will
bear witness of itself.
And so, we could close the
books on the article right here,
allowing those who revere NewsLetter authority to believe every
last line with "unquestioned
devotion", and leaving everyone
else to come and see for themselves what The Way is really all
about if they're genuinely interested, or to stay at home if they
aren't.
But as we lay to rest an
article that is either a brilliant
expose or one of the most
ludicrous pieces of yellow journalism ever published, permit me
to voice for ponderance a few
questions I find difficult to
reconcile ill my mind.
The first of these surely has
more than myself perplexed,
that is, why the News-Letter
would go to such lengths and
spend so much time taking a
crack at a student organization
which it obviously feels is having
little or no impact on campus
anyway. Judging from the contents of last week's issue, I
daresay you have more profitable ways to spend your time,
like covering items of wider
student interest, describing
porno flicks, and publishing such
things as guides to sleazy living
replete with the most edifying of
photographs.
And just for the record, you
might want to clarify which
students say "No Way to The
Way." Were they an accurate
representation of the hundreds
of members of the Hopkins
community who have attended

Twig fellowships over the past
several years and those who have
taken the Power For Abundant
Living class?
Or were you
referring to the handful or so
Ms. Taylor dug out of those
discontent to interview?
And merely because I consider it humorous, perhaps you
could explain why someone
who described herself as an
avowed atheist would put in
such a nice plug for the Hopkins
Christian Fellowship at the end
of her article. If I were in with
the IV boys, I'd look askance at
such a promotion...it's almost
like Hitler recommending the
local synagogue for spiritual
enlightenment.
While you reflect on these
points of query, there's a possibility you might also like to
consider this--The Way is a
fellowship of the followers of
the Lord Jesus Christ for the
manifestation of the more abundant life. And we never said
that means having piles .of
money. What it does mean is
answers, it means keys and
principles that anyone can know
and operate, it means living life
the way it was designed to be
lived. And for that kind of
knowledge you've got to go to
the source, God and His Word.
We've never said that we
have ALL the answers, or that
we've cornered the market on
truth. What we have said is that
we endeavor to rightly divide the
Word of God so that we can find
answers. Hey, aren't you tired
of guessing?
There's a lot more to be
said, and we are going to continue saying it. Those that have
ears to hear, let THEM hear, and
for those that don't, they can let
their kids figure it out.
Sincerely,
Sue Matesic
The Way Campus Outreach

Thanks
To the editor:
I would just like to thank
Miss Resnick for the insights she
provided in her brilliant piece of
commentary concerning the
News-Letter editorial on national health insurance.
The points she makes about
the distance doctors travel to see
their patients and the length of
time they are forced to spend in
their treatment go a long way
toward proving the wisdom of
an old saw: History majors
know nothing about economics.
The public might also take
some enlightenment from the
fact that Miss Resnick's father
happens to be a prominent
Philadelphia cardiologist.
Roscoe Richards '79

Working on WJHU is a full-time occupation. It
means long hours spinning discs, splicing tapes, cutting
copy, fixing- wires, and shelving records (plus other
minor details like balancing budgets). A typical day for
me means getting up at 6 A.M. and preparing newscasts
at 8 A.M., 1 P.M. and 5:30 P.M. That means four hours.
There are meetings to be attended, which often run over
an hours. I spend two hours planning a four-hour
classical show, once a week. I spend one or two evenings
attending lectures which are taped, and several hours in
production time. Out of a 24-hour day, I could easily
spend 25% with matters concerning WJHU. That may
not seem like much, but I also have a full work load.
There are lesser concerns such as sleeping and eating.
The strange part of this whole thing is that my case is
not unusual. There are members of the station much
more involved that I who spend a majority of their time
at WJHU. It's much like an iceberg; 90% of the work
cannot be seen. The sweat that goes into it is truly
incredible, and because people are not aware and don't
bother to listen, WJHU is truly the perfect situation
comedy. Or is it a tragedy?

ENCARE article."

The glitter of an FM station at 88 draws the unwary
towards their fate. "When we go FM" has become
something of a cant phrase at the station, tossed around
liberally by the ignorant. It is a catch-all used as a
safety-valve to release the frustrations of a group ot
people who are working hard and see no tangible returns. This safety-valve works only when people realize
what FM really means; for a very long time, they have
asked: "Is it worth it? Is all this effort really worth it?"
After all, why shouldn't they ask this? WJHU is the
butt of many jokes:
Q: "Hey, did you hear the one about WJHU?"

I can't begin to tell you how annoying it is to hear:"I
didn't even know we had a radio station," or"Gee, I
can hardly pick it up... better put another gerbel in the
engine, heh-heh."
It's gotten to the point where people on the station
are beginning to doubt their own sanity. Why should a
person spend hours on a program (or at a meeting, or in
a production session) when no one is listening?
My reply is this: Why should an actor spend hours
in a dress rehearsal reading lines to an empty theatre?
Should an actor wait until opening night to start learning
the lines? That would be crazy. Likewise, it would be
insane for us not to spend time on the radio when no
one is listening. For now FM approaches, and we should
all have learned our lines.

Shields and Robinson: Their Aim is True
The buffet was sensuous and the drinks proved to
be a wonderful aphrodisiac. I felt a very suggestive voice
beckoning me with that classically seductive opener,
Hi! What's your major?"
piroetted in a style indicative of my crocked
demeanor, and felt a lump the size of a bowling ball
growing in my throat. The voice behind me belonged to
an absolutely repulsive figure, a Jappish babe decked out
. a ifrighteningly familiar outfit: Lacoste, polyester
chinos, and fake L.L. Bean duck shoes. Her teeth were
Slightly curved, her manner resembled Linda Ronstadt's
cont. on s.lO

We zany college kids have our problems, of course.
I don't know who doesn't. For starters, we are not paid
for our efforts. We aren't given credits by the University. (In fact, there isn't even a mass media and communications department for pre-unemployment students
like me.) So if there is any motivation to work for
WJHU, it is an internal one. A major problem is the
simple fact that WJHU, being student-run, has a high
turnover rate. People come, and especially as their work
loads increase, they go. The few hardy souls left are
burdened with the responsibility of providing knowledge
for the new arrivals.
Station personnel, being human beings, do have
conflicts among themselves. Most of these conflicts can

be worked out with a friendly talk. Some of the arguments develop into feuds (and even outright vendettas),
but life goes on. So will FM.
General Staff Meetings are loose forums on the ideas
that have been generated by members of the station.
These confabs also provide the opportunity for people
to complain about whatever they feel is worth complaining about. For the most part the meetings are silly,
because they are attended by two types of people:
those who care, and those who don't. The former group
is highly motivated and can often get things discussed
and done without the GSM. The latter want to get back
to the library as quickly as possible. And then there are
those who never leave the library in the first place.
WJHU has also developed its own bureaucracy,
which, in the grand tradition of most bureaucracies, is
rather inefficient. This, I suspect, is so because of
the large number of people actually involved with the
station.
"I'd like to get a tape done."
"Oh you would, would you? Well, did you see the
traffic manager?"
"No."
"Did you sign the production schedule sheet?"
"No."
"Did you order the reels?"
"Well, do all of these things, and do them well, and
then I shall consider letting you go to the ball."

...signifying nothing.

Radio broadcasting is more than just a hobby. It's a
way of life. I take that back; it is life. My GPA has gone
down faster than the inflation rate has gone up. I
haven't gone out in weeks. I get very little sleep. And
for what, you ask?
Compare it to writing a fifty-page research paper.
You research it, write it, rewrite it, type it, and then

when you hand it in, the professor throws it in the trash
can. Well, soon we won't be in the trash can anymore. I
have always tried to work on the assumption that it
should make no difference whether one person or one
thousand people are listening--my work should be as
good as possible. Obviously this is a hard ideal to realize.
Now, along with an inner satisfaction, I will get 20.
additional satisfaction of knowing that the work I co,
and that others do, will benefit the community.
Meanwhile, however, with my social life shot to
hell, with paper assignments coming out of my ears, with
the prospect of getting up at 6 A.M., and worst of
all knowing that the damn ribbon has to be changed
again, I once again attempt to juggle the twin 16-ton
weights of radiowork and schoolwork. I am not alone,
thank God. My story is similar to everybody else's. We
all ask ourselves that same annoying question: Why am I
doing this? In the words of my good friend and ex-News
Director Dan Lebar,
"Because it's FUN!"

An hour later, feeling slightly cheapened but otherwise contented, Shields and I emerged from an upstairs
chamber. As our devastated bodies stumbled down the
catacombed stairs, our heads involuntarily nodded to the
finest in European disco. "This shit is bad," I noted.
Shields suggested that we send our colpague Steve
Randall down to give us an assessment of the sounds.
To make sure we didn't immediately fall flat on our
faces, we headed for the bar, our pens burning with the
ideas that you have just read, kind reader.
We got it all down, but then we realized had had it.
Writer's block- the nememsis of the aspiring journalist.
All our ideas were down, where do we for from here?
I was about to break the block by writing this slick
chick's number of my palm when I noticed Shield's
expression had suddenly contorted until he bore an
unholy resemblance to Maurice White of Earth, Wind
and Fire.
"I smell something," he shouted, "I smell something else!"
Inching his way towards us was a handsome young
Jamaican, replete with dreadlocks. Knocking the joint
9ut of my hand, he gleefully declared,"You can't smoke
none o'dat, mon. You got to smoke one a'dese like a
true Rasta."
He proffered a spliff which made Shields' Rolling
Writer look like a candy cigarette. It took a while to
dispose of the business at hand; it seems that they

playedall of "Natty Dread" and part of "The Harder
They Come" by the time half the spliff was gone. We
were all singing Peter Tosh's "Legalize It" by the time
we were done. The Jamaican took a truly gargantuan
hit, exhaled a giant cloud of smoke, and was gone.
"Ah, well, " we sighed, "Let's go get suburban."
I don't remember how many hours we spent in that
place; I don't remember seeing anything for a very long
time. All I remember was being tossed out the front
door by a then-naked Millard Savage.
Shields and I stumbled around the front lawn and
decided to head towards our car. We must have dented
about 26 cars in an attempt to find our '62 Porsche

356SC in the parking lot. I noticed Shields leaning over
face first against a black limo. I ran to him, he pointed
in the window, and we both took a gander. A woman
looking very much like Jackie 0. and some guy were
really going at it. We nodded at each other, disrobed,
and acquiesced to Jackie's promise to help us find our
car--later, she said, much later.

Show Of Virtuoso
Inventiveness By
Honsinger &Pals
On Thursday, February 15, the JHU
Fine Arts Committee presented the trio
consisting of Tristan Honsinger on cello,
Perry Robinson on clarinet, and Hal
Onserud on bass. Such an instrumental
combination is rather unusual for jazz,
but it can yield beautiful results, as
evidenced by this performance.
Three collective improvisations, a
solo clarinet piece, and a final improvisational duet for cello and bass were
presented, with no commentary or titles
given beforehand. The three musicians
were consistently creative and they
projected an energy and enthusiasm that
made the music especially communicative. In any free music, some of the
repeated ideas partly stem from the
learned playing techniques associated
with each instrument. Honsinger, Robinson, and Onserud have all had classical
training and experience, and this figures
prominently in their sound, from Robinson's turns to Honsinger's rich vibrato
and glissandos.
Onserud's exposure
to Cecil Taylor's "unit structures"(which
are highly lyrical but virtually devoid
of chord changes) and Robinson's eclectic
jazz background have also influenced the
trio's overall sound.
The musicians exploited the unique
tonal qualities of their instruments
to produce a wide range of effects.
Honsinger and Onserud played below the

IIlbw:—

Tristan Honsinger

bridge, rubbed the strings and surface of
their instruments with hands, allowed the
bow to bounce on the strings, and simultaneously bowed and plucked the strings.
Honsinger's improvisations were mainly
vertical combinations based on a scale, in
many ways analogous to Coltrane's modal
techniques. He was able to emphasize
certain pitches .over others and impose
harmonic structures, primarily ostinatos
or drones, on this field, sometimes
moving out of key into atonality. By
abandoning conventional bass positions
and freely using his bass as a percussive
instrument, Onserud could participate
much more directly in the music rather
than functioning as an "accompaniment."
His playing provided a melodic and
dissonant counterpoint, not merely a
means of keeping time for the group.
Robinson's playing was the most controlled and premeditated, but was equally
inventive. Split tones, harmonics, and
tense upper-register cries were combined
with smooth jazz riffs. His more traditional phrasing was effectively contrasted
with accents of bass and cello.
The trio generally employed a
theme-and-variation format. The theme
would fade in and out, passed from
instrument to instrument (and transformed in the process), or would be
maintained by one player (usually clarinet), while the other two improvised
around it. Within this format one could
detect a layering of sound from each
instrument, each layer following somewhat different organizational principles.
The resulting confluences and chance
encounters between layers were fascinating. One got an impression of disintegration and reformation, divergence and
convergence as the musical lines went off
on frenzied tangents then fell back into
the layered pattern.
The musicians
continually brought the music to the
verge of chaos, then restored unity
quickly or in slow and subtle stages. The
internal rhythm of the music was plastic
and could readily change its shape.
The first and longest piece introduced the audience to several common
aspects of the trio's performance. It
began with a melodic Philip Glass-like
structure (unison and ostinato variations)

which acted as a base to which the music
would return when it "converged."
Honsinger accompanied himself with a
vague scat vocal, including whistling,
growling, clicking, grunting, howling, etc.
Onserud joined him in making these
sounds. The effect was often deliberately
comic but added to the interplay of
similar instrumental sounds. Onserud
achieved interesting spatial effects by
rotating his bass as he bowed it. Both
players' facial expressions and movements
added a humorous visual element to the
performance. At one point, Honsinger
brought some hangers from a coatrack

NEWS-LETTER I PAGE 11
and "played" these along with the bass
and clarinet. This led to a mini-drama in
which Honsinger went behind the stage
and had to be coaxed out by Robinson,
who walked about playing, while Onserud
danced around his bass, then played it in
a horizontal position on the floor. After
a vocal-clarinet dialogue between Honsinger and Robinson, the trio reassembled
and and brought the piece to a conclusion, Robinson playing flowing melodies
on individual sections of the clarinet
(which he had taken apart). This clever
use of theater creates a new basis for
communication with the audience and is
an extension of the impromptu, intuitive,
exstatic qualities that distinguish jazz
from other comtemporary musics. When
they desired, the trio could change the
proceedings into a musical theater of the
absurd, full of emotion, possessing its
own meaningless language of phonetic
noises.
The second piece featured a pizzicato
duet by the cello and bass and remarkable
oscillating tones from the clarinet. A
subdued section of deep bass gave way to
a fairly conventional eighth-note line
before plunging into a series of short,
stabbing phrases, swirling triplets, and
interplay among the instruments. Theatrics included Honsinger dancing with an
invisible partner while Robinson played a
waltzy tune, and Honsinger telling an
absurdist fable over a sorrowful string
dirge. The piece became choppy and
disconnected, then re-formed into what
might be called jazz hoedown.
The clarinet solo consisted of variations on an A-G-F-C riff, with rapid
switching from high to low register; later,
the fourth piece was built around a
similar clarinet pattern. This penultimate
piece had a chant-like quality: grinding
strings and many short repetitive phrases.
The players would often suspend lines
and leave them airborne without making
customary resolutions.
Outstanding
spatial effects were achieved when
Onserud slowly moved around the outer
perimeter of the performing area. The
final piece was a showcase for Honsinger,
who walked around while playing,
looking like Ian Anderson with a cello. It
contained some excellent dialogues between bass and cello, and a long "scat
dialogue" between Onserud and Honsinger.
The trio's performance was engrossing and, moreover, enjoyable listening.
It was a good example of modern jazz at
its best--a synthesis of serious and popular
forms created by musicians with improvisatory freedom and artistic virtuosity.
--Mark Skoner

knocks out a boxer who insults him when
he's delivering sandwiches from his
father's deli. The boy later takes up the
coach's offer to become a boxer when his
sister needs $25,000 for an eye operation.
During his rise to stardom, the boy falls
in with the inevitable gamblers and loose
women, renouncing them in the end for
his old coach, his old girlfriend, and his
family. In the second movie, a girl from a
boarding school in New York comes to
the Big Apple and, by a stroke of luck,
lands a part in a Broadway musical. The
boy, a clumsy accountant with a yearning

by the producer and writes a smash hit;
like the boxer, he has his fill of high life
and fancy women before rejecting them
for good old-fashioned virtues. The
producer, with only one month to live,
puts on his greatest hit despite financial
and other complications, and dies with
the sound of applause ringing in his ears.
The two movies not only parody the
1940's plots; they also mimic their
verbal and cinematic cliches. Nearly every
line is corny and uttered in the tradition

Cont. from p. 11
present the greatest obstacle the young
pianist must overcome to gain recognition. Continued superior performances in
piano competitions usually begins to
make heads turn. But Graf also notes
that a final barrier, for any artist, is to
perform in New York, and be written up
in the New York Times,
This past summer, Graf received his
greatest prize thus far, winning the
University of Maryland Piano Competition. Since then, he has been giving
recitals extensively, and gaining a strong
reputation wherever he has played. And
while that all important New York date
may be on the horizon, Graf demonstrated a few weeks ago, in his only Baltimore
recital this year, that he commands a
keyboard genius and sensibility deserved
of world-wide recognition.
Grars recital was a no-holds barred
display of his massive capabilities at the
piano. His performances of Bach, Beethoven, Pozdro, Chopin and Liszt were
restrained and disciplined. The tone,
rhythm and dynamics of each piece was
played with extreme precision and care,
The performances weren't sterile, but
from each note, Graf was able to express
millions of moods nuances and meta-

phors. His exacting style and concern for
all the elements of the music made his
recital, emotional and extremely beautiful.
Beethoven's Sonata in C minor (op.
111) was the composer's thirty-second
and final sonata. It was comosed when
he was deaf, and, if not over the edge, on
the brink of madness. In the second
movement, the sonata builds to a motif
which sounds distinctly jazzy to twentieth century ears, but which pre-dates
any notions of jazz by nearly a hundred
years. Many pianists would try to coverup this motif, claiming that to play it
as jazz--as it is written--would be a
chronological incongruity. Graf does the
opposite, and plays this motif to the hilt.
Applying his vast knowledge of musical
styles, Graf makes this 'quirk' in Beethoven's mind as expressive as if it had been
written fifty years ago.
This boldness is indicative of Grars
performance. He would not hold back a
single emotion or feeling, but interpreted
and played them with a commanding
creative intelligence which is expected
from only the greatest of the great
pianists.
--Stephen Barr

The Men's Varsity Basketball team closed out its 197c
season Saturday night by dropping a contest to Washington
College by the score of 62-47.
The defeat was the Jays' 12th in

100 points, while a perfect set of
three targets (a feat seldom

a score of 300 points.

SC Still Debates
Conduct Code
BY PETER CINQUEGRANI
The Legal Rights Committee, headed by Cindy Simon, is
now working on the third draft
of the Conduct Code which it
hopes to have ready for referendum by March.
The code was originally
scheduled for completion in the
fall. Problems in acclimating the
new Student Council, the administrative reorganization which
caused communication difficulties and growing problems for the
Student Council in other areas
all delayed work on the Code.
Two factions are debating
what form the code will finally
take. The side headed by Simon
favorss a code which would "set
up general guidelines as to what

offenses the University will use
its own sanctions against." The
code as she conceives it would
deal soley with non-academic
offences, actions which would
directly or materially damage or
threaten the "health, safety and
welfare of the University community or damage the physical
facilities of the University." No
off-campus student activities
would come under the jurisdiction of the Code.
Accused students could
choose to have their cases heard
by either a Judicial Board
composed of five students or by
one of the deans. The proposkj
Code also calls for an appellate
process.

BY HARRY LERNER
On Tuesday, February 13,
frigid weather and hot tempers
created an ugly scene on the
10 am shuttle going to the East
Baltimore campus. The 9:30
shuttle never arrived. When
the 10:00 shuttle arrived, a
crowd of 60 would-be riders had
gathered to crowd onto the bus.
The problem increased when
those who had just arrived
pushed their way on ahead of
some people who had been
waiting for up to an hour in the
cold.
The driver, Bill Dorrell,
refused to leave with riders
standing in the aisle and on the
steps, but no passengers would
get off. Finally he, radioed the
Magsamen Bus Co. for instruc-

tions, and they called Hopkins
Secuirty. Four officers, including Security Manager Robert
Larkin, responded to the call.
Mark Warren, a medical
student, says that the Security
officers flew into a rage. He says
they were "screaming as loud as
they could, 'get off the bus or
we'll throw you off." Warren
admits that the riders' response
was,"if they didn't get down (to
East Baltimore) why should
anyone get down" and that
there was "verbal abuse back
and forth." He thinks "there
should have been an attempt to
reach an equitable solution, "
such as asking those who had
just arrived to wait, or putting
the University van into service.
Dr. Paul McHugh, Director

Reefer Reform 'letters to the editorl
It is a strange paradox that the increased use of the
drug cannabis among "respectable" middle-class citizens
seems if anything to have led to a more complacent
attitude toward the law forbidding the possession of
marijuana. But in the words of national NORML director
Larry Schott, "Pot has become so commonplace, it's not a
cultural symbol any more."
Yet the outlawed status of marijuana remains one of
the biggest single travesties perpetrated by the government
on our society today. The official hypocrisy engendered
by the current situation rivals the disastrous spectacle of
Prohibition. The frequent and flagrant flouting of the
marijuana law not only weakens the moral force of that
particular statute, it also subverts respect for the role of
law in an entire generation of citizens. Such a trend
cannot be tolerated; no society can be strong unless the
laws it establishes are enforced and observed to the fullest
extent by its good members.
In spite of the widespread disregard for the penalties
concerning cannabis consumption, the law takes a heavy
toll. Over 470,000 people were arrested in this country last
year on such charges, an all-time high. Of these cases, 90%
were for simple possession. The continued illegitimacy of
marijuana makes respectable citizenship quite tenuous for
anyone who uses the drug.
There are no solid reasons why growing, owning, and
smoking pot should remain illegal. The short-term effects
of the drug are in many respects comparable to those of
alcohol, which is allowed. However, it is much less disruptive of physical coordination, and there is no unpleasant
after-effect—read hangover. Neither have harmful long-term
effects been proven for moderate marijuana users. Used to
excess, like alcohol, cigarettes, or even food, it can wreck a
life.
In any case, since marijuana affects only people who
choose to use it, our government has no sacred right to
forbid the substance. Of course, in one important situation
a person's decision to get high could affect others, that is,
when that person is planning to drive an automobile. A
simple test has fortunately been devised to detect .drivers
under the influence of marijuana. Such "high driving"
should be subject to severe penalties just like drunk driving
now is.
The so-callocd "decriminalization" of marijuana which
has been introduced into some jurisdictions is but a
compromising solution at best. Traffic-sized fines for
marijuana violations arc even more hypocritical then the
present system, if that is possible. Only with total legalizadon of the distribution and possession of cannabis products can our society return to a sane. rational course.

Drivel
To the Editor:
It is with humble sincerity
that I submit this apology to
anyone who might have misconstrued the intent of my
previous letter (Hicks, January
26 issue). I am from a small
town in West Virginia where one
could not spit down Main street
on breezy day without hitting
one of my relatives. Needless to
say, any "degrading" remarks
pertaining to Mountain people
were strictly unintentional.
I was taken aback, however,
at the suppressive tone of "Slur
Stir" (February 9 issue). It is
my understanding that the first
amendment to the Constitution
(an excellent document, and I
recommend that those responsible for "Slur Stir" subject it to
perusal some evening when not
out crusading) guarantees that
freedom of the press shall not be
abridged. I expect that the
composers of this illiberal epistle
advocate censorship of the
News-Letter (themselves to be
the censors, no doubt).
"Slur Stir" might be passed
off as well intentioned drivel if it
did not contain implicit advocation of suppression of the free
press. The News-Letter is to be
commended for its willingness to
print even so reactionary an
opinion.
George Stanton

Way Out
To the Editor:
You know, if some things
weren't worth taking a stand for,
it wouldn't make a bit of difference what the administration
did to the Hopkins custodial
schedule...or what happened to
Ric Pfeffer...or how many
people were exterminated under
Mao Tse-Tung's regime...or how
a nation once begged to have a
murderer released to them that
they might crucify an innocent
man.
And when there isn't a
sufficient portion of the population willing to take a stand
against such injustices, they go
on and on, leaving succeeding
generations to clean up the mess.
Yet the guilt falls not solely into
the 'hands of those who perpetrate deceit, but also into the
hands of those who. stand idly
by. supposing that they are not
affected, nor responsible for
their own destiny.
As for myself, it would be
but a simple thing to shrug my
shoulders, finish writing my
thesis, and disappear into the
sunset, never again having to

concern myself with Hopkins or
the Twig fellowship I've coordinated here for the past few
years...And then it wouldn't
make a bit of difference what
Daisy Taylor wrote in last
week's News-Letter about The
Way.
But that's not the course I
choose to follow. It's not that
I'm so eminently noble, or
exceedingly virtuous, or endowed with wisdom that will
perish with my demise. Nor is it
that I follow The Way with
"blind devotion", and have sold
my soul to but a vain endeavor,
relishing in continual deceit of
my colleagues and peers, for I
am none of the above.
Yet I have taken a stand,
and will not begin to presume
that I have not the responsibility
to stLe what I know is true. I
trust that those who were
interested enough to read Ms.
Taylor's article will give at least
equal consideration to this point
of view.
This is not a complaint, nor
an attempt to set the record
straight. The article stands on
its own merits, or falls by its
lack thereof.
In the same
respect, if what we of The Way
believe and teach is truth, it will
bear witness of itself.
And so, we could close the
books on the article right here,
allowing those who revere NewsLetter authority to believe every
last line with "unquestioned
devotion", and leaving everyone
else to come and see for themselves what The Way is really all
about if they're genuinely interested, or to stay at home if they
aren't.
But as we lay to rest an
article that is either a brilliant
expose or one of the most
ludicrous pieces of yellow journalism ever published, permit me
to voice for ponderance a few
questions I find difficult to
reconcile ill my mind.
The first of these surely has
more than myself perplexed,
that is, why the News-Letter
would go to such lengths and
spend so much time taking a
crack at a student organization
which it obviously feels is having
little or no impact on campus
anyway. Judging from the contents of last week's issue, I
daresay you have more profitable ways to spend your time,
like covering items of wider
student interest, describing
porno flicks, and publishing such
things as guides to sleazy living
replete with the most edifying of
photographs.
And just for the record, you
might want to clarify which
students say "No Way to The
Way." Were they an accurate
representation of the hundreds
of members of the Hopkins
community who have attended

Twig fellowships over the past
several years and those who have
taken the Power For Abundant
Living class?
Or were you
referring to the handful or so
Ms. Taylor dug out of those
discontent to interview?
And merely because I consider it humorous, perhaps you
could explain why someone
who described herself as an
avowed atheist would put in
such a nice plug for the Hopkins
Christian Fellowship at the end
of her article. If I were in with
the IV boys, I'd look askance at
such a promotion...it's almost
like Hitler recommending the
local synagogue for spiritual
enlightenment.
While you reflect on these
points of query, there's a possibility you might also like to
consider this--The Way is a
fellowship of the followers of
the Lord Jesus Christ for the
manifestation of the more abundant life. And we never said
that means having piles .of
money. What it does mean is
answers, it means keys and
principles that anyone can know
and operate, it means living life
the way it was designed to be
lived. And for that kind of
knowledge you've got to go to
the source, God and His Word.
We've never said that we
have ALL the answers, or that
we've cornered the market on
truth. What we have said is that
we endeavor to rightly divide the
Word of God so that we can find
answers. Hey, aren't you tired
of guessing?
There's a lot more to be
said, and we are going to continue saying it. Those that have
ears to hear, let THEM hear, and
for those that don't, they can let
their kids figure it out.
Sincerely,
Sue Matesic
The Way Campus Outreach

Thanks
To the editor:
I would just like to thank
Miss Resnick for the insights she
provided in her brilliant piece of
commentary concerning the
News-Letter editorial on national health insurance.
The points she makes about
the distance doctors travel to see
their patients and the length of
time they are forced to spend in
their treatment go a long way
toward proving the wisdom of
an old saw: History majors
know nothing about economics.
The public might also take
some enlightenment from the
fact that Miss Resnick's father
happens to be a prominent
Philadelphia cardiologist.
Roscoe Richards '79

I've got a great new idea for a hit T.V. series. It'll
be about the antics of a zany bunch of students (in a
prestigious university of a major Northeastern metropolitan area) who are trying to run a radio station and
pass all their courses at the same time. It can't miss. It's
a natural situation comedy.
Situation comedy is the story of our lives, and
sometimes the line between comedy and tragedy cannot
be drawn too distinctly. The hit series could be based
on the real-life story of a university radio station called
WJHU. This is their story seen through my eyes. If I
fail to portray it accurately, what can I say except it's
my version of the truth?

Working on WJHU is a full-time occupation. It
means long hours spinning discs, splicing tapes, cutting
copy, fixing- wires, and shelving records (plus other
minor details like balancing budgets). A typical day for
me means getting up at 6 A.M. and preparing newscasts
at 8 A.M., 1 P.M. and 5:30 P.M. That means four hours.
There are meetings to be attended, which often run over
an hours. I spend two hours planning a four-hour
classical show, once a week. I spend one or two evenings
attending lectures which are taped, and several hours in
production time. Out of a 24-hour day, I could easily
spend 25% with matters concerning WJHU. That may
not seem like much, but I also have a full work load.
There are lesser concerns such as sleeping and eating.
The strange part of this whole thing is that my case is
not unusual. There are members of the station much
more involved that I who spend a majority of their time
at WJHU. It's much like an iceberg; 90% of the work
cannot be seen. The sweat that goes into it is truly
incredible, and because people are not aware and don't
bother to listen, WJHU is truly the perfect situation
comedy. Or is it a tragedy?

The glitter of an FM station at 88 draws the unwary
towards their fate. "When we go FM" has become
something of a cant phrase at the station, tossed around

what FM really means; for a very long time, they have

After all, why shouldn't they ask this? WJHU is the

It's gotten to the point where people on the station

My reply is this: Why should an actor spend hours
in a dress rehearsal reading lines to an empty theatre?
Should an actor wait until opening night to start learning
the lines? That would be crazy. Likewise, it would be
insane for us not to spend time on the radio when no
one is listening. For now FM approaches, and we should
all have learned our lines.

Shields and Robinson: Their Aim is True
The buffet was sensuous and the drinks proved to
be a wonderful aphrodisiac. I felt a very suggestive voice
beckoning me with that classically seductive opener,
Hi! What's your major?"
piroetted in a style indicative of my crocked
demeanor, and felt a lump the size of a bowling ball
growing in my throat. The voice behind me belonged to
an absolutely repulsive figure, a Jappish babe decked out
. a ifrighteningly familiar outfit: Lacoste, polyester
chinos, and fake L.L. Bean duck shoes. Her teeth were
Slightly curved, her manner resembled Linda Ronstadt's
cont. on s.lO

We zany college kids have our problems, of course.
I don't know who doesn't. For starters, we are not paid
for our efforts. We aren't given credits by the University. (In fact, there isn't even a mass media and communications department for pre-unemployment students
like me.) So if there is any motivation to work for
WJHU, it is an internal one. A major problem is the
simple fact that WJHU, being student-run, has a high
turnover rate. People come, and especially as their work
loads increase, they go. The few hardy souls left are
burdened with the responsibility of providing knowledge
for the new arrivals.
Station personnel, being human beings, do have
conflicts among themselves. Most of these conflicts can

be worked out with a friendly talk. Some of the arguments develop into feuds (and even outright vendettas),
but life goes on. So will FM.
General Staff Meetings are loose forums on the ideas
that have been generated by members of the station.
These confabs also provide the opportunity for people
to complain about whatever they feel is worth complaining about. For the most part the meetings are silly,
because they are attended by two types of people:
those who care, and those who don't. The former group
is highly motivated and can often get things discussed
and done without the GSM. The latter want to get back
to the library as quickly as possible. And then there are
those who never leave the library in the first place.
WJHU has also developed its own bureaucracy,
which, in the grand tradition of most bureaucracies, is
rather inefficient. This, I suspect, is so because of
the large number of people actually involved with the
station.
"I'd like to get a tape done."
"Oh you would, would you? Well, did you see the
traffic manager?"
"No."
"Did you sign the production schedule sheet?"
"No."
"Did you order the reels?"
"Well, do all of these things, and do them well, and
then I shall consider letting you go to the ball."

...signifying nothing.

Radio broadcasting is more than just a hobby. It's a
way of life. I take that back; it is life. My GPA has gone
down faster than the inflation rate has gone up. I
haven't gone out in weeks. I get very little sleep. And
for what, you ask?
Compare it to writing a fifty-page research paper.
You research it, write it, rewrite it, type it, and then

when you hand it in, the professor throws it in the trash
can. Well, soon we won't be in the trash can anymore. I
have always tried to work on the assumption that it
should make no difference whether one person or one
thousand people are listening--my work should be as
good as possible. Obviously this is a hard ideal to realize.
Now, along with an inner satisfaction, I will get 20.
additional satisfaction of knowing that the work I co,
and that others do, will benefit the community.
Meanwhile, however, with my social life shot to
hell, with paper assignments coming out of my ears, with
the prospect of getting up at 6 A.M., and worst of
all knowing that the damn ribbon has to be changed
again, I once again attempt to juggle the twin 16-ton
weights of radiowork and schoolwork. I am not alone,
thank God. My story is similar to everybody else's. We
all ask ourselves that same annoying question: Why am I
doing this? In the words of my good friend and ex-News
Director Dan Lebar,
"Because it's FUN!"

An hour later, feeling slightly cheapened but otherwise contented, Shields and I emerged from an upstairs
chamber. As our devastated bodies stumbled down the
catacombed stairs, our heads involuntarily nodded to the
finest in European disco. "This shit is bad," I noted.
Shields suggested that we send our colpague Steve
Randall down to give us an assessment of the sounds.
To make sure we didn't immediately fall flat on our
faces, we headed for the bar, our pens burning with the
ideas that you have just read, kind reader.
We got it all down, but then we realized had had it.
Writer's block- the nememsis of the aspiring journalist.
All our ideas were down, where do we for from here?
I was about to break the block by writing this slick
chick's number of my palm when I noticed Shield's
expression had suddenly contorted until he bore an
unholy resemblance to Maurice White of Earth, Wind
and Fire.
"I smell something," he shouted, "I smell something else!"
Inching his way towards us was a handsome young
Jamaican, replete with dreadlocks. Knocking the joint
9ut of my hand, he gleefully declared,"You can't smoke
none o'dat, mon. You got to smoke one a'dese like a
true Rasta."
He proffered a spliff which made Shields' Rolling
Writer look like a candy cigarette. It took a while to
dispose of the business at hand; it seems that they

playedall of "Natty Dread" and part of "The Harder
They Come" by the time half the spliff was gone. We
were all singing Peter Tosh's "Legalize It" by the time
we were done. The Jamaican took a truly gargantuan
hit, exhaled a giant cloud of smoke, and was gone.
"Ah, well, " we sighed, "Let's go get suburban."
I don't remember how many hours we spent in that
place; I don't remember seeing anything for a very long
time. All I remember was being tossed out the front
door by a then-naked Millard Savage.
Shields and I stumbled around the front lawn and
decided to head towards our car. We must have dented
about 26 cars in an attempt to find our '62 Porsche

356SC in the parking lot. I noticed Shields leaning over
face first against a black limo. I ran to him, he pointed
in the window, and we both took a gander. A woman
looking very much like Jackie 0. and some guy were
really going at it. We nodded at each other, disrobed,
and acquiesced to Jackie's promise to help us find our
car--later, she said, much later.

On Thursday, February 15, the JHU
Fine Arts Committee presented the trio
consisting of Tristan Honsinger on cello,
Perry Robinson on clarinet, and Hal
Onserud on bass. Such an instrumental
combination is rather unusual for jazz,
but it can yield beautiful results, as
evidenced by this performance.
Three collective improvisations, a
solo clarinet piece, and a final improvisational duet for cello and bass were
presented, with no commentary or titles
given beforehand. The three musicians
were consistently creative and they
projected an energy and enthusiasm that
made the music especially communicative. In any free music, some of the
repeated ideas partly stem from the
learned playing techniques associated
with each instrument. Honsinger, Robinson, and Onserud have all had classical
training and experience, and this figures
prominently in their sound, from Robinson's turns to Honsinger's rich vibrato
and glissandos.
Onserud's exposure
to Cecil Taylor's "unit structures"(which
are highly lyrical but virtually devoid
of chord changes) and Robinson's eclectic
jazz background have also influenced the
trio's overall sound.
The musicians exploited the unique
tonal qualities of their instruments
to produce a wide range of effects.
Honsinger and Onserud played below the

IIlbw:—

Tristan Honsinger

bridge, rubbed the strings and surface of
their instruments with hands, allowed the
bow to bounce on the strings, and simultaneously bowed and plucked the strings.
Honsinger's improvisations were mainly
vertical combinations based on a scale, in
many ways analogous to Coltrane's modal
techniques. He was able to emphasize
certain pitches .over others and impose
harmonic structures, primarily ostinatos
or drones, on this field, sometimes
moving out of key into atonality. By
abandoning conventional bass positions
and freely using his bass as a percussive
instrument, Onserud could participate
much more directly in the music rather
than functioning as an "accompaniment."
His playing provided a melodic and
dissonant counterpoint, not merely a
means of keeping time for the group.
Robinson's playing was the most controlled and premeditated, but was equally
inventive. Split tones, harmonics, and
tense upper-register cries were combined
with smooth jazz riffs. His more traditional phrasing was effectively contrasted
with accents of bass and cello.
The trio generally employed a
theme-and-variation format. The theme
would fade in and out, passed from
instrument to instrument (and transformed in the process), or would be
maintained by one player (usually clarinet), while the other two improvised
around it. Within this format one could
detect a layering of sound from each
instrument, each layer following somewhat different organizational principles.
The resulting confluences and chance
encounters between layers were fascinating. One got an impression of disintegration and reformation, divergence and
convergence as the musical lines went off
on frenzied tangents then fell back into
the layered pattern.
The musicians
continually brought the music to the
verge of chaos, then restored unity
quickly or in slow and subtle stages. The
internal rhythm of the music was plastic
and could readily change its shape.
The first and longest piece introduced the audience to several common
aspects of the trio's performance. It
began with a melodic Philip Glass-like
structure (unison and ostinato variations)

which acted as a base to which the music
would return when it "converged."
Honsinger accompanied himself with a
vague scat vocal, including whistling,
growling, clicking, grunting, howling, etc.
Onserud joined him in making these
sounds. The effect was often deliberately
comic but added to the interplay of
similar instrumental sounds. Onserud
achieved interesting spatial effects by
rotating his bass as he bowed it. Both
players' facial expressions and movements
added a humorous visual element to the
performance. At one point, Honsinger
brought some hangers from a coatrack

NEWS-LETTER I PAGE 11
and "played" these along with the bass
and clarinet. This led to a mini-drama in
which Honsinger went behind the stage
and had to be coaxed out by Robinson,
who walked about playing, while Onserud
danced around his bass, then played it in
a horizontal position on the floor. After
a vocal-clarinet dialogue between Honsinger and Robinson, the trio reassembled
and and brought the piece to a conclusion, Robinson playing flowing melodies
on individual sections of the clarinet
(which he had taken apart). This clever
use of theater creates a new basis for
communication with the audience and is
an extension of the impromptu, intuitive,
exstatic qualities that distinguish jazz
from other comtemporary musics. When
they desired, the trio could change the
proceedings into a musical theater of the
absurd, full of emotion, possessing its
own meaningless language of phonetic
noises.
The second piece featured a pizzicato
duet by the cello and bass and remarkable
oscillating tones from the clarinet. A
subdued section of deep bass gave way to
a fairly conventional eighth-note line
before plunging into a series of short,
stabbing phrases, swirling triplets, and
interplay among the instruments. Theatrics included Honsinger dancing with an
invisible partner while Robinson played a
waltzy tune, and Honsinger telling an
absurdist fable over a sorrowful string
dirge. The piece became choppy and
disconnected, then re-formed into what
might be called jazz hoedown.
The clarinet solo consisted of variations on an A-G-F-C riff, with rapid
switching from high to low register; later,
the fourth piece was built around a
similar clarinet pattern. This penultimate
piece had a chant-like quality: grinding
strings and many short repetitive phrases.
The players would often suspend lines
and leave them airborne without making
customary resolutions.
Outstanding
spatial effects were achieved when
Onserud slowly moved around the outer
perimeter of the performing area. The
final piece was a showcase for Honsinger,
who walked around while playing,
looking like Ian Anderson with a cello. It
contained some excellent dialogues between bass and cello, and a long "scat
dialogue" between Onserud and Honsinger.
The trio's performance was engrossing and, moreover, enjoyable listening.
It was a good example of modern jazz at
its best--a synthesis of serious and popular
forms created by musicians with improvisatory freedom and artistic virtuosity.
--Mark Skoner

old Hollywood traditions--poor boy
makes good as a boxer and unknown girl
subs for the lead actress and becomes a
star. Both movies are riddled with structural cliches. In the first movie, a boy,
studying at night to be a law student,
knocks out a boxer who insults him when
he's delivering sandwiches from his
father's deli. The boy later takes up the
coach's offer to become a boxer when his
sister needs $25,000 for an eye operation.
During his rise to stardom, the boy falls
in with the inevitable gamblers and loose
women, renouncing them in the end for
his old coach, his old girlfriend, and his
family. In the second movie, a girl from a
boarding school in New York comes to
the Big Apple and, by a stroke of luck,
lands a part in a Broadway musical. The
boy, a clumsy accountant with a yearning
to write Broadway musicals, is discovered
by the producer and writes a smash hit;
like the boxer, he has his fill of high life
and fancy women before rejecting them
for good old-fashioned virtues. The
producer, with only one month to live,
puts on his greatest hit despite financial
and other complications, and dies with
the sound of applause ringing in his ears.
The two movies not only parody the
1940's plots; they also mimic their
verbal and cinematic cliches. Nearly every
line is corny and uttered in the tradition

ENlifIQUE GRAF

Cont. from p. 11
present the greatest obstacle the young
pianist must overcome to gain recognition. Continued superior performances in
piano competitions usually begins to
make heads turn. But Graf also notes
that a final barrier, for any artist, is to
perform in New York, and be written up
in the New York Times,
This past summer, Graf received his
greatest prize thus far, winning the
University of Maryland Piano Competition. Since then, he has been giving
recitals extensively, and gaining a strong
reputation wherever he has played. And
while that all important New York date
may be on the horizon, Graf demonstrated a few weeks ago, in his only Baltimore
recital this year, that he commands a
keyboard genius and sensibility deserved
of world-wide recognition.
Grars recital was a no-holds barred
display of his massive capabilities at the
piano. His performances of Bach, Beethoven, Pozdro, Chopin and Liszt were
restrained and disciplined. The tone,
rhythm and dynamics of each piece was
played with extreme precision and care,
The performances weren't sterile, but
from each note, Graf was able to express
millions of moods nuances and meta-

phors. His exacting style and concern for
all the elements of the music made his
recital, emotional and extremely beautiful.
Beethoven's Sonata in C minor (op.
111) was the composer's thirty-second
and final sonata. It was comosed when
he was deaf, and, if not over the edge, on
the brink of madness. In the second
movement, the sonata builds to a motif
which sounds distinctly jazzy to twentieth century ears, but which pre-dates
any notions of jazz by nearly a hundred
years. Many pianists would try to coverup this motif, claiming that to play it
as jazz--as it is written--would be a
chronological incongruity. Graf does the
opposite, and plays this motif to the hilt.
Applying his vast knowledge of musical
styles, Graf makes this 'quirk' in Beethoven's mind as expressive as if it had been
written fifty years ago.
This boldness is indicative of Grars
performance. He would not hold back a
single emotion or feeling, but interpreted
and played them with a commanding
creative intelligence which is expected
from only the greatest of the great
pianists.
--Stephen Barr

The Men's Varsity Basketball team closed out its 197c

mark to 4-18, 2-8 in the Middle
Atlantic Conference.
The Washington College loss
came despite the strong efforts

line for a game high of17 points,
and Dan Jackson, who collected
10 points and was strong under
the rebounding boards. The
Jays took a one point lead

who combined for 32 points.
